Award.AwardTitle: Clarion University Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Proposal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Clarion University's Venango Campus is piloting a NanoManufacturing concentration within its Industrial Technology 2-year associates in applied science degree (AAS-IT), which provides workforce proficiency in nanotechnology. The students receive an AAS in Industrial Technology and a NanoFabrication Manufacturing Technology (NMT) certificate from Penn State University. The NanoManufacturing concentration within the AAS-IT requires the core math and science courses of 4-year science degrees, an immersion semester at Penn State University's Nanofabrication Center and a practical capstone offered as a NanoManufacturing course. The NanoManufacturing capstone course is a hands-on lecture and laboratory course that provides fundamental skills necessary to work in a nanotechnology production environment and to prepare the students for the immersion semester. The course discusses theoretical concepts behind research, development, production, and processing of nano-scaled materials. The course is conducted within the Center for Applied Research & Intellectual Property Development in order to expose the students to local industries. The courses at Penn State University are offered through the ATE National Center NACK. The project is providing an increased educational foundation for technicians to keep up with the rapid development in the current and emerging industrial fields. The project has outreach to regional K-12 schools, teachers, displaced workers, veterans, and has established a regional industry advisory board.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Clarion University Advanced Technological Education grant was ambitious in its goals of recruitment and development. The Venango College at Clarion University has a strong history of preparing students for associate degrees in industrial technology and technology administration, yet the grant program did not realize the level of success that was anticipated.  The primary marketing goal was to market the program to area high schools by providing information to guidance counselors and science teachers. In particular, the outreach plan called for targeting schools that have a strong STEM focus such as magnet and charter schools that specifically focus on STEM. The outreach plan also called for targeting high schools that enrolled high proportions of racial/ethnic minority students, schools located in the Pittsburgh metro area, and schools located in rural areas. A final component of the outreach plan was to market the program to veterans and those dislocated from prior employment. In all of these phases, the PI and his team found recruitment to the program challenging. While the program, as written, was not successful, the lessons learned both in recruitment and curriculum have been viewed as highly valuable both regionally and nationally (for rural, low economic areas). Please see below for specific details.

The NW region of Pennsylvania has been plagued by both declining high school enrollment, in part due to relocation of manufacturing plants, and general population decline. In addition, our regional universities in the PASSHE system are experiencing an unprecedented drop in enrollment. The rural setting of Clarion and its surrounding communities includes a large number of low income families and first generation college students. The objective identified in the proposal to recruit from STEM focused schools was not possible, as those don’t exist in the region. Similarly, the recruitment plan to our 2-year associate degree, to date, is primarily regional.  Over the life of the program, we have records of visiting 23 high schools/vocational schools with an average of 6 students attending per visit. These visits netted zero enrollment into the program. The industrial technology recruitment strategies employed attracted students who were seeking general education plus trade-specific coursework, not advanced science and mathematics courses. In addition, students were unable to financially afford residing at Pennsylvania State University for the quarter of in depth nanoscale training.

The ultimate goal of this program provide the skill for students to be employable in a world where understanding emerging technology is important. We still introduced the concepts of nanotechnology and how it is integrated into current manufacturing practices, but we also included introductions to:

  • Quality control
  • LEAN manufacturing
  • Six sigma
  • Electricity basics
  • How to recognize component wear

The program staff found that the literature created for the advertisement and recruitment of students out of high school was too technical and that the placement in guidance offices without face to face visits was unsuccessful. For future growth, the PI would:

  • enter local schools, specifically in physics classes, earlier in the academic year and work with the secondary education providers to speak plainly about the program and the benefits of certification.
  • work with the school district science faculty to identify students who would be most successful in the program
  • send literature (in non-technical language) to parents. Many students in the recruitment pool are considered first generation college students; and the overly technical nature of the literature did not help in the recruitment goals.
